edu.eur.absa.algorithm

Class AbstractAlgorithm

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.eur.absa.algorithm.AbstractAlgorithm
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    CheatingAspectCategoryClassificationAlgorithm, CheatingAspectPolarityClassificationAlgorithm, CheatingHeadlinesSentimentRegressionAlgorithm

    public abstract class AbstractAlgorithm
extends java.lang.Object
    AbstractAlgorithm is the template class that every Algorithm should subclass. It comes loaded with useful features and methods that can be used in any Algorithm. Following this template will ensure your algorithm can automatically be run and evaluated by the system.
    Author:
    Kim Schouten

      protected java.util.Properties properties
      Properties can be used to model different variants of the same algorithm without copying the whole algorithm class for only a small change, or changing the code all the time

      The DataEntities that are in the test set are stored separately, this is used in the evaluation method The reason this is different from dataSubSets is that how you split your data might not be the same as what thing you are interested in and predicting.

      The Span type which is used to divide the dataset for this algorithm

    • Field Detail

      • predictions

        protected java.util.HashMap<DataEntity,java.util.HashSet<Prediction>> predictions
        The predictions that are created by an algorithm are stored here.

      • evaluators

        protected java.util.HashSet<Evaluator> evaluators
        The things that can be evaluated based on the output of the algorithm for example, different evaluators can evaluate classification results or regression results. If your algorithm produces more than one type of annotation, you can simply add more evaluators so each type of output produced by your algorithm is properly evaluated.

      • features

        protected java.util.HashMap<? extends DataEntity,java.util.HashSet<java.lang.String>> features
        Features to cache, this is useful in e.g. cross-validation where an algorithm is run multiple times. Caching the textual features is a good time saver.

      • dataSubSets

        protected java.util.ArrayList<java.util.HashSet<Span>> dataSubSets
        the training, validation, test splits of the data

      • testAnnotatables

        protected java.util.HashSet<DataEntity> testAnnotatables
        The DataEntities that are in the test set are stored separately, this is used in the evaluation method The reason this is different from dataSubSets is that how you split your data might not be the same as what thing you are interested in and predicting.

      • label

        protected java.lang.String label
        A descriptive label for this algorithm which is used in printing the output.

      • properties

        protected java.util.Properties properties
        Properties can be used to model different variants of the same algorithm without copying the whole algorithm class for only a small change, or changing the code all the time

      • unitOfAnalysisSpanType

        protected java.lang.String unitOfAnalysisSpanType
        The Span type which is used to divide the dataset for this algorithm

      • targetSpanType

        protected java.lang.String targetSpanType
        The Span which is the target for this algorithm. The training and test set should be sets of Spans of this spanType.

      • dataset

        protected Dataset dataset
        A reference to the dataset

    • Constructor Detail

      • AbstractAlgorithm

        public AbstractAlgorithm(java.lang.String label,
                         java.lang.String unitOfAnalysisSpanType)
        Every new Algorithm should at least specify a label and the unit of analysis. By default, the targetSpanType is the same as the unitOfAnalysisSpanType
        Parameters:
        label - A descriptive label for this algorithm which is used in printing the output.
        unitOfAnalysisSpanType - The Span type which is used to divide the dataset for this algorithm

      • AbstractAlgorithm

        public AbstractAlgorithm(java.lang.String label,
                         java.lang.String unitOfAnalysisSpanType,
                         java.lang.String targetSpanType)
        Constructor that allows targetSpanType to be different than unitOfAnalysisSpanType. The latter is used to split the dataset into training/test/etc. While the former is used to actually test against when evaluating. For instance, you can split the data by review, but since you want to evaluate whether you assigned the right aspectCategory spans to each sentence span, the targetSpanType = "sentence"
        Parameters:
        label -
        unitOfAnalysisSpanType -
        targetSpanType -

    • Method Detail

      • clean

        public void clean()
        The high-level clean algorithm that cleans this algorithm so it is ready for another run (e.g., the next fold in cross-validation). Note that this method will call the cleanAlgorithm method which is in your own custom Algorithm class. Make sure you reset all essential variables in that method to avoid data leakage.

      • setDataSubSets

        public void setDataSubSets(java.util.ArrayList<java.util.HashSet<Span>> dataSubSets,
                           Dataset dataset)
        A method to set the data subsets (e.g., training, validation, test set) for this Algorithm
        Parameters:
        dataSubSets - The data subsets for training, validation, testing, etc.

      • cleanAlgorithm

        protected abstract void cleanAlgorithm()
        This is the local clean algorithm, as referred to by the global clean() method. This method should be implemented in each Algorithm. The clean() method, and thus cleanAlgorithm() as well, is called first when running an Algorithm

      • preprocess

        public abstract void preprocess()
        The preprocess method is called after cleaning is performed and can be used to do some costly data preprocessing that does not have to be repeated over multiple runs. For instance, you can usually already extract the textual features from all pieces of text and store them in features, as these normally do not change over different runs.

      • train

        public abstract void train()
        The train method is called after preprocessing and is used to train your Algorithm. Here, you can use the gold standard annotation to tune paramters, train machine learning models, etc. This method is repeated everytime the Algorithm is run. Variables resulting from this method, like the trained model or parameters, have to be cleaned first to ensure valid results.

      • predict

        public abstract void predict()
        The predict method uses the trained model or tuned parameters from the train method to make predictions on previously unseen data. Your implementation should create Prediction objects which should be stored in the prediction map as the evaluation method will look there for your results.

      • evaluate

        public EvaluationResults evaluate(Evaluator evaluator)
        Specify a specific Evaluator to evaluate the predictions of this Algorithm.
        Parameters:
        evaluator - The Evaluator to be used when evaluating this Algorithm
        Returns:
        An EvaluationResults object that contains the performance of this Algorithm

      • evaluate

        protected EvaluationResults evaluate(Evaluator evaluator,
                                     java.util.HashSet<? extends DataEntity> testAnnotatables)
        Evaluate this Algorithm, given an Evaluator and a test set.
        Parameters:
        evaluator - The Evaluator to be used when evaluating this Algorithm
        testAnnotatables - The test set to compare the predictions against
        Returns:
        An EvaluationResults object that contains the performance of this Algorithm

      • executeAndShowResults

        public java.lang.String executeAndShowResults()
        Execute this algorithm from scratch, including the preprocessing step
        Returns:
        A textual report of the evaluation results

      • executeAndShowResults

        public java.lang.String executeAndShowResults(boolean preprocess)
        Execute this algorithm and specify whether the preprocessing step has to be performed
        Parameters:
        preprocess - Perform the preprocess step if true
        Returns:
        A textual report of the evaluation results

      • executeAndReturnResults

        public java.util.HashMap<java.lang.Class<? extends Evaluator>,EvaluationResults> executeAndReturnResults()
        Execute this algorithm from scratch, including the preprocessing step.
        Returns:
        A set of EvaluationResults object that contain the evaluation results of each task

      • executeAndReturnResults

        public java.util.HashMap<java.lang.Class<? extends Evaluator>,EvaluationResults> executeAndReturnResults(boolean preprocess)
        Execute this algorithm and specify whether the preprocessing step has to be performed
        Parameters:
        preprocess - Perform the preprocess step if true
        Returns:
        A set of EvaluationResults object that contain the evaluation results of each task

      • getTestAnnotatables

        protected java.util.HashSet<? extends DataEntity> getTestAnnotatables()
        Within an Algorithm, it is sometimes necessary to get the actual test set
        Returns:
        The test set

      • getTestData

        protected java.util.HashSet<Span> getTestData()
        Get the data subset that corresponds to the test set
        Returns:
        The test data subset

      • getCombinedData

        protected java.util.HashSet<Span> getCombinedData()
        Return all spans in a single HashSet (useful for the preprocess method) The distinction between training/test/etc set is lost, so be careful to not use this in the train() method
        Returns:
        All data as Spans of type unitOfAnalysisSpanType

      • getTrainingData

        protected java.util.ArrayList<java.util.HashSet<Span>> getTrainingData()
        Get all training data, which is all subsets (also for validation etc.) except the test data subset
        Returns:
        All subsets except the test set

      • getCombinedTrainingData

        protected java.util.HashSet<Span> getCombinedTrainingData()
        Get all training data from (maybe) different subsets into one set. If there is a validation set, it is combined with the training data
        Returns:
        All subsets extent the test set, but flattened into a single HashSet

      • annotateTestData

        public void annotateTestData()
        Method to encode the predictions into the data model so the resp. DataWriter can write it back to the proper file format

      • getUnitOfAnalysisSpanType

        public java.lang.String getUnitOfAnalysisSpanType()
        Returns:
        Get the unit of analysis span, that is used to divide the data into subsets

      • getEvaluators

        public java.util.HashSet<Evaluator> getEvaluators()
        Returns:
        Get the set of Evaluators used to evaluate this Algorithm

      • getPrediction

        public java.util.HashSet<Prediction> getPrediction(Span s)
        Parameters:
        s - The Span for which predictions were made
        Returns:
        The predictions that fall within this Span.

      • getLabel

        public java.lang.String getLabel()
        Returns:
        The descriptive label of this Algorithm

      • setProperty

        public AbstractAlgorithm setProperty(java.lang.String key,
                                     java.lang.String value)
        Set a property of this Algorithm, so you can have different variants of the same Algorithms
        Parameters:
        key - The property key
        value - The property value
        Returns:
        This Algorithm, so you chain these methods

      • setBinaryProperties

        public AbstractAlgorithm setBinaryProperties(java.lang.String... keys)
        Set a binary property for this Algorithm, which are simply flags that are present or not Only the presence of the property key is tested, so the value is empty
        Parameters:
        keys - The property key
        Returns:
        This Algorithm, so you chain these methods

      • hasProperty

        public boolean hasProperty(java.lang.String key)
        Get whether a given property key is present or not. This is mostly used with binary properties.
        Parameters:
        key - The property key to check
        Returns:
        True when this key is present, false otherwise

      • getProperty

        public java.lang.String getProperty(java.lang.String key)
        Get the value corresponding to a given property key. This is only useful for non-binary properties.
        Parameters:
        key - The property key to get the value of
        Returns:
        The value that corresponds to the given property key

      • getPropertyOrDefault

        public java.lang.String getPropertyOrDefault(java.lang.String key,
                                             java.lang.String defaultValue)
        Get the value corresponding to a given property key. This is only useful for non-binary properties. You can supply a default value to use when the given key is not present. This is useful to prevent having to put getProperty() within an if block to check for its existence first.
        Parameters:
        key - The property key to get the value of
        defaultValue - The value to use when the key is absent
        Returns:
        The value for the given key if present, provided default value otherwise
